Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 33   Filed 05/31/16   Page 6 of 30
 
1  Without any evidence or legal support, Plaintiffs charge that San Francisco’s Department of 
2  Elections (“Department”) has violated the Constitution, the Voting Rights Act, and California law by 
3  failing to adequately inform voters who have not expressed a party preference (“NPP” voters) that they 
4  can vote in the Democratic, Libertarian, or American Independent presidential primaries on the June 7, 
5  2016 election, and by failing to adequately inform voters who have expressed a party preference that 
6  they can change that preference.  This is hogwash.  The Department has engaged in a massive public 
7  outreach effort over the last four months to educate voters about these precise issues and provide them 
8  with the means to select the presidential primary in which they’d like to vote.  Among many other 
9  efforts, the Department has sent a mailer to all NPP voters who have applied to vote by mail informing 
10  them that they can vote in one of the presidential primaries by submitting an attached, postage paid 
11  form.  Similarly, all NPP voters who go to the Department’s website to look up their registration status 
12  or apply to vote by mail will see that, to vote in a presidential primary, they must fill out a form that 
13  they can access by clicking on a link.  The Department has also sent a Voter Information Pamphlet 
14  (“VIP”) to every registered San Francisco voter explaining how NPP voters can vote in a presidential 
15  primary, and on the back of every VIP sent to an NPP voter is a form that the voter can submit to the 
16  Department indicating the primary in which he or she would like to vote.  In addition, the Department 
17  trains poll workers to inform NPP voters at the polling place on Election Day that they may vote in a 
18  presidential primary, and every polling place has a sign that contains this information.  The 
19  Department’s efforts to inform voters who have selected a party preference how to change that 
20  preference have been just as extensive. 
21  Ignoring the Department’s outreach campaign entirely, Plaintiffs assert a variety of baseless 
22  legal claims.  First, Plaintiffs assert that the Department has violated two provisions of the Voting 
23  Rights Act, 52 U.S.C. § 10101(a)(2)(A) and 10101(a)(2)(B).  But the first provision on which Plantiffs 
24  rely applies only to voter registration practices, and is inapplicable to this case.  And the second 
25  provision restricts registrars from omitting material information from voter materials, when the 
26  Department did just the opposite here.   Second, Plaintiffs argue that the Department has violated the 
27  First Amendment and the Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause by supposedly failing to 
28  provide sufficient information to NPP voters about their right to vote in a presidential primary.  This 
Opp. of S.F. Dept. of Elections to Mot. for Prelim. Inj.  1 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01110025.docx
Case No. 16-CV-2739-WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 33   Filed 05/31/16   Page 7 of 30
 
1  claim fails because, far from burdening the voting rights of San Franciscans, the Department has gone 
2  to great lengths to help San Franciscans fulfill those rights.  Third, Plaintiffs argue that the Department 
3  has violated a provision of the California Elections Code that requires the Department to inform NPP 
4  voters that they may vote in a presidential primary.  As a legal matter, Plaintiffs’ claim fails because 
5  the statute under which they are seeking relief—28 U.S.C. § 1361—applies exclusively to violations 
6  of law by federal officials, not state or local officials.  And as a factual matter, Plaintiffs’ claims fail 
7  because the Department went above and beyond its statutory duty to educate all voters about voting in 
8  the presidential primary and their right to change their party preference.   
9  In addition to not establishing a likelihood of success on the merits, Plaintiffs have also fallen 
10  short on every other element of the test for a preliminary injunction.  See Winter v. Natural Resources 
11  Defense Council, Inc., 555 U.S. 7 (2008).  There has been no irreparable injury—indeed, there has 
12  been no injury whatsoever—as the Department has provided Plaintiffs, like all San Francisco voters, 
13  with all required information regarding which presidential primaries they can vote in and how to 
14  change their party preference.  Any alleged injury to Plaintiffs or any San Francisco voters is so 
15  speculative that even Plaintiffs are unable to articulate a concrete harm.  In addition, the balance of 
16  hardships and the public interest weigh strongly against a preliminary injunction here.  The remedies 
17  Plaintiffs seek are impossible, unnecessary, and/or unwarranted, and would sow confusion on the eve 
18  of Election Day.  For these reasons, the Court should deny the motion for preliminary injunction. 
FACTUAL BACKGROUND 
19 
I.  SAN FRANCISCO’S DEPARTMENT OF ELECTIONS. 
20 
The Department conducts all federal, state and local elections in San Francisco.  Declaration of 
21 
John Arntz (“Arntz Dec.) ¶ 2.  Serving nearly 467,000 registered voters, the Department must ensure 
22 
that the City meets all applicable legal deadlines, that it has adequate staff and equipment to provide 
23 
election services, that the recording and tabulation of votes is accurate and secure, and that voting 
24 
equipment and polling places are usable and accessible to voters.  See id.  For the presidential primary 
25 
election on June 7, 2016, the Department has hired approximately 250 temporary employees, 
26 
including more than 30 dedicated to voter services and outreach.  See id.  On Election Day, the 
27 
Department will manage 576 polling places staffed by 2,500 volunteer poll workers.  See id. 
28 
Opp. of S.F. Dept. of Elections to Mot. for Prelim. Inj.  2 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01110025.docx
Case No. 16-CV-2739-WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 33   Filed 05/31/16   Page 8 of 30
 
1  Federal, state and local law closely regulate and prescribe nearly every aspect of the 
2  Department’s operations to ensure that San Francisco’s elections are fair and functional.  See id. ¶ 3.  
3  In compliance with these laws, the Department must adhere to a strict schedule to complete essential 
4  tasks for each election, including: ordering ballot supplies; preparing and printing ballots; mailing 
5  overseas and other vote-by-mail (formerly known as absentee) ballots; printing and distributing 
6  information to the voters; training employees and poll workers; testing the accuracy of every voting 
7  machine that will be used in the election; counting and tabulating votes; and conducting a mandatory 
8  post-election hand count to verify election results.  See id. ¶ 3.   
II.  THE PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY ELECTION ON JUNE 7, 2016. 
9 
10  When registering to vote in California, a person has the option of selecting a political party 
11  preference.  See id. ¶ 4.  Voters who register to vote without stating a party preference are known as 
12  “No Party Preference” or NPP voters.  See id.  Each political party has the option of allowing NPP 
13  voters to vote in its presidential primary.  See id.  For California’s presidential primary election on 
14  June 7, 2016, three political parties have chosen to allow NPP voters to vote on their presidential 
15  primary ballot:  the Democratic Party, the American Independent Party, and the Libertarian Party.  See

San Francisco voters had applied to receive vote-by-mail ballots and the ballots those voters should

Plaintiffs have also taken issue with the fact that the Department’s ballot replacement request

form states that the Department must receive the request by June 1.  In Plaintiffs’ view, June 1 is

ARGUMENT 
8 
9  “A plaintiff seeking a preliminary injunction must establish that he is likely to succeed on the 
10  merits, that he is likely to suffer irreparable harm in the absence of preliminary relief, that the balance 
11  of equities tips in his favor, and that an injunction is in the public interest.”  Winter v. Natural 
12  Resources Defense Council, Inc., 555 U.S. 7, 20 (2008).  Plaintiffs fall short on every element of the 
13  Winter test.   
I.  PLAINTIFFS CANNOT ESTABLISH A LIKELIHOOD OF SUCCESS ON THE 
14 
MERITS.   
15  A.  The Department Did Not Violate the Voting Rights Act. 
16 
Plaintiffs argue that the Department violated two provisions of the Voting Rights Act—52 
17 
U.S.C. § 10101(a)(2)(A) and 52 U.S.C. § 10101(a)(2)(B).  Neither of those provisions applies here. 
18 
Subsection (A) states: 
19  No person acting under color of law shall in determining whether any individual 
is qualified under State law or laws to vote in any election, apply any standard, 
20  practice, or procedure different from the standards, practices, or procedures 
applied under such law or laws to other individuals within the same county, 
21  parish, or similar political subdivision who have been found by State officials to 
be qualified to vote.... 
22 
That provision “was designed to eliminate practices that could encumber an individual’s ability 
23 
to register to vote.”  Friedman v. Snipes, 345 F.Supp.2d 1356, 1371 (S.D. Fla. 2004) (citing Schwier v. 
24 
Cox, 340 F.3d 1284, 1297 (11th Cir. 2003).  In Friedman, which Plaintiffs cite as “the best guidance in 
25 
this situation,” see Docket No. 29 at 20, the court rejected the plaintiff’s Voting Rights Act claim 
26 
because “[t]he error and omission alleged here did not pertain to determining eligibility to vote.”  345 
27 
F.Supp.2d at 1372.  Like Friedman, this case has nothing to do with voter registration.  Rather,

8  Subsection (B), in other words, “prohibits denying the right to vote based on errors or

13  registration requirements to disenfranchise African–Americans.”  Id.

B.  The Department Did Not Violate the Constitution.  
1 
Plaintiffs claim that the Department violated the First Amendment and the Fourteenth 
2 
Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause.  To assess the constitutionality of election laws, courts apply a 
3 
“flexible standard” that weighs the burdens of such regulation against the government’s interests in 
4 
enacting those laws.  Burdick v. Takushi, 504 U.S. 428, 434 (1992).  Focusing on “the extent to which 
5 
a challenged regulation burdens First and Fourteenth Amendments rights,” the Court has applied the 
6 
following test:   
7 
 . . . when those rights are subjected to severe restrictions, the regulation must be 
8  narrowly drawn to advance a state interest of compelling importance.  But when 
a state election law provision imposes only reasonable, nondiscriminatory 
9  restrictions upon the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights of voters, the 
State’s important regulatory interests are generally sufficient to justify the 
10  restrictions. 
11 
Id. at 434 (quotations and citations omitted).  If the burden is severe, the regulation is subject to strict 
12 
scrutiny; if the challenged regulation is reasonable and nondiscriminatory, it may be justified by 
13 
important regulatory interests.  The Supreme Court and the Ninth Circuit have consistently applied this 
14 
balancing approach in considering First Amendment, Due Process, and Equal Protection challenges to 
15 
election laws.  See Dudum v. Arntz, 640 F.3d 1098, 1106 n.15 (9th Cir. 2011); Lemons v. Bradbury, 
16 
538 F.3d 1098, 1103 (9th Cir. 2008).  Courts have occasionally described the test for reasonable, 
17 
nondiscriminatory regulations as a “rational basis” test, Libertarian Party of Washington v. Munro, 31 
18 
F.3d 759, 761 (9th Cir. 1994), under which a plaintiff must demonstrate that the challenged regulation 
19 
is “not rationally related to a legitimate state interest.”  Arizona Libertarian Party v. Reagan, 798 F.3d 
20 
723, 733-34 (9th Cir. 2015).   
21 
Applying this standard, the courts have upheld a myriad of election regulations as reasonable 
22 
and non-discriminatory, even where there is a significant possibility that they would burden voters.  
23 
See, e.g., Crawford v. Marion County Election Board, 553 U.S. 181, 185, 202-03 (2008) (plurality 
24 
opinion) (voter identification); Rosario v. Rockefeller, 410 U.S. 752, 760-62 (1973) (advance 
25 
enrollment requirement for party primary elections); Burns v. Fortson, 410 U.S. 686, 686-87 (1973) 
26 
(requirement that voters register at least 50 days prior to election); Marston v. Lewis, 410 U.S. 679, 
27 
680-81 (1973) (requirement that voters reside in jurisdiction for 50 days prior to registration); see also 
28

2  that states may restrict the voting privilege through residency and other requirements.”).   
3    In the present case, Plaintiffs cannot meet their burden.  Indeed, it is difficult to even evaluate 
4  Plaintiffs’ constitutional claim since it is unclear what that claim actually entails.  To the extent 
5  Plaintiffs are claiming that it was unconstitutional for the Department not to provide the statement in 
6  Elections Code § 3006(c) to both NPP and non-NPP voters, this argument fails.  That statement is 
7  designed specifically to provide information to NPP voters, and it would be unduly confusing for

11  presidential primary election and the implications of being an NPP voter or being a party-affiliated 
12  voter.  Far from burdening the voting rights of San Franciscans, the Department has gone to great 
13  lengths to help San Franciscans realize those rights.  
14    To the extent that Plaintiffs’ constitutional claim relies on the use of the April 18 deadline, that 
15  claim is meritless as there is no evidence that the use of this deadline burdened voting rights of even 
16  one person, and even if it did, that burden was minimal and justified by the Department’s operational 
17  needs.  To the extent that Plaintiffs’ constitutional claim relies on the supposedly erroneous use of the 
18  June 1 deadline on the replacement ballot request form, that claim fails because it imposes no burden 
19  on voters; and it is justified by the operational needs of the Department.

20 
Fails. 
21  1.  The Statute Under Which Plaintiffs Seek Mandamus Relief—28 U.S.C. § 
1361—Does Not Authorize An Injunction Against a Local Official for

23 
Plaintiffs seek a writ of mandamus under 28 U.S.C. § 1361.  However, that statute does not 
24 
authorize federal courts to enjoin the conduct of state or local officials.  The statute states: “The 
25 
district courts shall have original jurisdiction of any action in the nature of mandamus to compel an 
26 
officer or employee of the United States or any agency thereof to perform a duty owed to the plaintiff.”  
27 
(emphasis added).  Because Director Arntz is not an officer or employee of the United States,

2  applications to the Department, and anyone who called the Department’s help desk would receive the 
3  same information. 
II.  PLAINTIFFS HAVE NOT SUFFERED AND WILL NOT SUFFER ANY INJURY, 
4 
MUCH LESS AN IRREPARABLE ONE. 
5 
A preliminary injunction may only be granted when the moving party has demonstrated a real 
6 
likelihood of irreparable injury or harm.  Winter, 555 U.S. at 21.  “Speculative injury does not 
7 
constitute irreparable injury sufficient to warrant granting a preliminary injunction.  A plaintiff must 
8 
do more than merely allege imminent harm sufficient to establish standing; a plaintiff must 
9 
demonstrate immediate threatened injury as a prerequisite to preliminary injunctive relief.”  Caribbean 
10 
Marine Servs. Co., Inc. v. Baldridge, 844 F.2d 668, 674 (9th Cir. 1988) (emphasis in original; internal 
11 
citations omitted).  A preliminary injunction cannot issue based only on the possibility of some remote 
12 
future injury because “injunctive relief [is] an extraordinary remedy that may only be awarded upon a 
13 
clear showing that the plaintiff is entitled to such relief.”  Winter, 555 U.S. at 22. 
14 
  Because interim injunctions “are generally granted under the theory that there is an urgent need 
15 
for speedy action to protect the plaintiffs’ rights,” a plaintiff’s delay “tends to indicate at least a 
16 
reduced need for such drastic, speedy action.”  Citibank v. Citytrust, 756 F.2d 273, 276 (2d Cir. 1985).  
17 
“By sleeping on its rights a plaintiff demonstrates the lack of need” for preliminary relief.  Lydo 
18 
Enterprises, Inc. v. City of Las Vegas, 745 F.2d 1211 (9th Cir. 1984) (cites and quotes omitted).  A 
19 
“long delay before seeking a preliminary injunction implies a lack of urgency and irreparable harm.”  
20 
Oakland Tribune, Inc. v. Chronicle Pub. Co., 762 F.2d 1374, 1377 (9th Cir. 1985). 
21 
Plaintiffs have failed to demonstrate that they or any San Francisco voter will suffer an injury, 
22 
much less an irreparable one.  As described above, the Department has gone to great lengths to educate 
23 
NPP voters that they can vote in one of the presidential primaries and non-NPP voters that they re-
24 
register.  All NPP voters who vote at a polling place will be informed (both by poll workers and by a 
25 
sign) that they can vote in one of the primaries.  All NPP voters who applied to vote by mail have been 
26 
informed on multiple occasions that they can vote in one of the primaries.  Similarly, the Department’s 
27 
outreach efforts have informed all San Francisco residents that they can register and/or re-register to 
28 
Opp. of S.F. Dept. of Elections to Mot. for Prelim. Inj.  23 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01110025.docx
Case No. 16-CV-2739-WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 33   Filed 05/31/16   Page 29 of 30
 
1  vote.  Finally, the fact that Plaintiffs’ waited 15 days to seek relief—from May 13 when their lawyer 
2  first contacted the Department until May 28 when they filed the instant motion—undercuts the 
3  credibility of their claims about the existence and magnitude of injury that would befall the San 
4  Francisco electorate without emergency relief.   
III.  THE BALANCE OF HARDSHIPS AND PUBLIC INTEREST STRONGLY FAVOR 
5 
DENYING PLAINTIFFS’ MOTION. 
6 
In “balanc[ing] the hardships of the public interest against a private interest, the public interest 
7 
should receive greater weight.”  Fed. Trade Comm’n v. Affordable Media, LLC, 179 F.3d 1228, 1236 
8 
(9th Cir. 1999) (quoting Fed. Trade Comm’n v. World Wide Factors, Ltd., 882 F.2d 344, 347 (9th Cir. 
9 
1989)).  In the elections context, the Court should act with particular caution because “[c]ourt orders 
10 
affecting elections, especially conflicting orders, can themselves result in voter confusion and 
11 
consequent incentive to remain away from the polls.”  Purcell v. Gonzalez, 549 U.S. 1, 4-5 (2006).  
12 
For these reasons, the Supreme Court has counseled caution in the type of relief to be granted in cases 
13 
affecting elections: 
14 
In awarding or withholding immediate relief, a court is entitled to and should consider the 
15  proximity of a forthcoming election and the mechanics and complexities of state election laws, 
and should act and rely upon general equitable principles.  With respect to the timing of relief, 
16  a court can reasonably endeavor to avoid a disruption of the election process which might 
result from requiring precipitate changes that could make unreasonable or embarrassing 
17  demands on a State in adjusting to the requirements of the court’s decree. 
18  Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, 585 (1964). 
19  These principles strongly counsel against an injunction in this case.  All of the remedies sought 
20  by Plaintiffs are unnecessary and some of them are impossible.  One impossible remedy is to extend 
21  the voter registration deadline to Election Day.  As described in Director Arntz’s declaration, this 
22  remedy would likely be fatal to the Department’s ability to conduct the election.  Arntz Dec., ¶ 43.  
23  There are currently about 397,000 San Franciscans who have not registered to vote and millions more 
24  people throughout the state who have not registered.  See id.  Ordering Election Day registration 
25  would be tantamount to requiring the Department to allow every single person who showed up at a 
26  polling place on Election Day to cast a ballot.  See id.  If this happened, the election would be plunged 
27  into chaos, as the Department has not prepared for such vast numbers of people, nor could the 
28  Department prepare for such numbers in such a short time.  See id.   
Opp. of S.F. Dept. of Elections to Mot. for Prelim. Inj.  24 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01110025.docx
Case No. 16-CV-2739-WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 33   Filed 05/31/16   Page 30 of 30
 
1  Planning for and running an election is an incredibly complex process that requires the 
2  Department to make a series of projections related to possible voter turnout.  See id. ¶ 44.  These 
3  projections inform the number of polling places; the number of ballots, provisional ballots, and ballot 
4  envelopes to order; the number of poll workers; the number of field support personnel; and countless 
5  other operational requirements.  See id.  The projections also inform the how the Department staffs 
6  and organizes the Voting Center at City Hall.  See id.  These projections are based on the registration 
7  totals from 15 days before an election.  See id.  The Department could not conduct the election if this 
8  Court ordered the Department to open the polls to 397,000 new San Francisco voters plus the millions 
9  of non-San Francisco voters who could attempt to vote in San Francisco on Election Day.  See id.     
10  The other remedies sought by Plaintiffs are unnecessary because the Department is already 
11  doing them.  The Department will already inform NPP voters who vote at a polling place that they can 
12  vote in a presidential primary.  The Department’s online vote-by-mail application already satisfies the 
13  requirements of Elections Code § 3006(c), and in any event, the deadline to apply to vote by mail is 
14  the same day as the hearing on Plaintiffs’ motion.  The Department is already widely distributing 
15  information that NPP voters can vote in a presidential primary.  The Department has already widely 
16  distributed the fact that voters can change their party preference, and in any event, the deadline for re-
17  registering was on May 23.  The Department has already ensured that sufficient ballots will be 
18  available at every polling place.   
19   “[E]lection cases are different from ordinary injunction cases, and “[i]nterference with 
20  impending elections is extraordinary.”  Southwest Voter Registration Educ. Project v. Shelley, 344 
21  F.3d 914, 919 (9th Cir. 2003).  There is no basis for such extraordinary intervention in this case. 
CONCLUSION 
22 
23  For the foregoing reasons, the Court should deny Plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary 
24  injunction.  
25  Dated:  May 31, 2016 
By:  /s/Joshua S. White   
26 
JOSHUA S. WHITE 
Attorney for Defendant JOHN ARNTZ 
27 
 
28 
Opp. of S.F. Dept. of Elections to Mot. for Prelim. Inj.  25 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01110025.docx

documents.text:
Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 46   Filed 06/02/16   Page 1 of 7
1
2
3
4
5
6 IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
7
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA
8
9
10
VOTING RIGHTS DEFENSE PROJECT, No. C 16-02739 WHA
AMERICAN INDEPENDENT PARTY OF
t 11
r CALIFORNIA,  CLARA DAIMS, and
u
SUZANNE BUSHNELL,
o a 12
C ni
ct  alifor 13 Plaintiffs,
i C
Distr strict of  14     v.
tates  orthern Di 15 AaosfL fSiEceiXcarl e PctAaarpDya IcoLiftL ySA atas, t iecn,h  JhieOifsH  ooNff ft ihAceiRa SlN acTnapZa, ciint yhis MMINEOJUMTNIOOCRNTA IFNOODNRU PMR OELPIINMIIONNA RRYE
S N 16
ited  For the  17 FDthrUea nPAcUliasImcSo,e  idDnae  hpCiasor uotmnffteiycn iRta ole fgc iaEsplteraaccrti itooyfn  aVss,  ocTtheIiMresf, of
n
U
18
Defendants.
                                                                     /
19
20
INTRODUCTION
21
In this action claiming statutory and constitutional violations relating to the
22
dissemination of information regarding procedures for the presidential primary, plaintiffs sought
23
a preliminary injunction.  The motion was denied on the record at a hearing.  This memorandum
24
opinion sets forth the reasoning for denial of that motion.
25
STATEMENT
26
This action concerns the dissemination of information regarding voting procedures for
27
the California presidential primary, which is scheduled to occur in six days on June 7, although
28
the vote-by-mail procedure began on May 9.  Under California law, an individual who declines
to disclose a preference for a political party when registering to vote (a “no-party-preference

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 46   Filed 06/02/16   Page 2 of 7
1 voter”), may nevertheless vote in a political party’s primary if that party has adopted a rule
2 permitting so-called “crossover ballots.”  A crossover ballot is the only means by which a no-
3 party-preference voter can vote for a presidential nominee in the upcoming primary.  The
4 Democratic Party, the American Independent Party, and the Libertarian Party have elected to
5 permit such crossover ballots.  (The Republican Party has not.)  Individuals affiliated with a
6 party participating in a given primary cannot obtain a crossover ballot to vote in another party’s
7 primary, although they could change their affiliation (including by changing to no party
8 preference) by May 23.  Put in practical terms, Republicans could have re-registered as no-
9 party-preference voters and then obtained a crossover ballot to vote in the Democratic primary,
10 provided they changed their affiliation on or before May 23, now more than a week ago. 
t 11 Plaintiffs are supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders and expect their relief will support his
r
u
o a 12 campaign.  Senator Sanders, however, has no part in this lawsuit.
C ni
  or
ct alif 13 Defendants Alex Padilla, Secretary of State of California, John Arntz, chief of the San
i C
tr of 
Dis strict  14 Francisco Department of Elections, and Tim Dupuis, chief of the Alameda County Registrar of
  Di
tates orthern  15 Voters, through their respective agencies, engaged in extensive efforts, including distributing
S N 16 information by mail and via the internet, hosting outreach and education events, and buying
ted  For the  17 advertisements in print media and on public transportation, regarding the rights of no-party-
i
n
U
18 preference voters to obtain crossover ballots in order to vote in the three presidential primaries
19 identified above.  Defendants also plan to display information about no-party-preference voters’
20 rights prominently at poll stations (Dupuis Decl., Exhs. A, D–F; Arntz Decl., Exhs. A–B, D,
21 F–I, K–T; Reyes Decl., Exhs. A–R).  Defendants have made similar efforts to inform voters that
22 they could re-register to vote for a different party or to remove any party affiliation by May 23
23 (e.g., Arntz Decl., Exh. B).
24 Plaintiffs’ theory in this case is that certain information disseminated as part of the
25 foregoing efforts has been inadequate or misleading.  They primarily take issue with the
26 contention that the poll workers in Alameda County have been trained not to affirmatively
27 inform no-party-preference voters of their rights to obtain a crossover ballot, while poll workers
28 in San Francisco (and other counties) have been instructed to affirmatively inform no-party-
2

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 46   Filed 06/02/16   Page 3 of 7
1 preference voters of that option.  They also note that no-party-preference voters received
2 applications to vote by mail that set a deadline of April 18 for any request for a crossover ballot,
3 and they received subsequent applications for replacement ballots (in case they later realized
4 they wanted a crossover ballot) with a deadline to make that request by June 1.  Finally, they
5 note that individuals that had indicated a party preference did not receive any information about
6 what their rights regarding crossover ballots would be should they choose to change their
7 registration.  
8 The Court’s ruling on the record followed briefing and oral argument heard on an
9 expedited schedule in order to allow more time for an emergency appeal before the primary. 
10 This memorandum opinion amplifies on that ruling.
t 11 ANALYSIS
r
u
o a 12 A plaintiff seeking a preliminary injunction must satisfy a four-part test established by
C ni
  or
ct alif 13 the Supreme Court in Winter v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., 555 U.S. 7 (2008). 
i C
tr of 
Dis strict  14 Specifically he must establish “that he is likely to succeed on the merits, that he is likely to
  Di
tates orthern  15 suffer irreparable harm in the absence of preliminary relief, that the balance of the equities tips
S N 16 in his favor, and that an injunction is in the public interest.”  Id. at 20.  Our plaintiffs fail at
ted  For the  17 every step.
i
n
U
18 1. PLAINTIFFS ARE NOT LIKELY TO SUCCEED ON THE MERITS.
19 A. Constitutional Claims.
20 Plaintiffs contend that defendants’ conduct constituted arbitrary discrimination in
21 violation of the First Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth
22 Amendment, but they cite no authority suggesting this conduct is anything close to a
23 constitutional violation.  In Burdick v. Takushi, 504 U.S. 428, 434 (1992), the Supreme Court
24 held that in the context of election regulations, we must apply a “flexible standard” that weighs
25 the burdens of the regulation against the government’s interest in enacting them.  If the burden
26 is severe, the regulation is subject to strict scrutiny, if not, it may be justified by important state
27 interests.  
28
3

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 46   Filed 06/02/16   Page 4 of 7
1 Here, the burden on no-party-preference voters, is slight, if it exists at all.  Voters must
2 read the materials provided to them to understand their rights; only some counties will spoon-
3 feed the information.  The government’s interests in arranging for an orderly and fair primary,
4 avoiding voter confusion by providing too much information, and ensuring that voters can
5 receive their ballots in a timely manner all plainly justify defendants’ conduct.
6 B. Voting Rights Act Claims.
7 Plaintiffs also contend that defendants violated Sections 10101(a)(2)(A) and (B) of Title
8 52 of the United States Code.  Section 10101(a)(2)(A) concerns voter registration, which is not
9 at issue here.  Section 10101(a)(2)(B), on the other hand, prohibits a state from denying the
10 right to vote “because of an error or omission on any record or paper relating to any application,
t 11 registration, or other act requisite to voting, if such error or omission is not material in
r
u
o a 12 determining whether such individual is qualified under State law to vote in such election.” 
C ni
  or
ct alif 13 Plaintiffs’ theory is that defendants have violated Section 10101(a)(2)(B) by omitting the
i C
tr of 
Dis strict  14 statements regarding no-party-preference voters from materials distributed to voters that had
  Di
tates orthern  15 indicated a party preference, but there is no evidence of the possibility that anyone may be
S N 16 denied the right to vote as a result of that omission.  Defendants have, in fact, extensively
ted  For the  17 campaigned to inform voters about their rights, so in the unlikely circumstance that a voter
i
n
U
18 timely removed her party affiliation but still sought to vote in a presidential primary via
19 crossover ballot, ample information has been disseminated to inform her of that right.  
20 Thus, plaintiffs have failed to show any likelihood of success on their Voting Rights Act
21 claims.
22 C. Claim for Mandamus.
23 Plaintiffs do not assert independent claims based on violations of state law but rather
24 seek a writ of mandamus under federal law compelling defendants to carry out certain alleged
25 duties under state law.  Plaintiffs cite Section 1361 of Title 28 of the United States Code as the
26 authority for that relief, but that provision only grants a district court authority to compel “an
27 officer or employee of the United States or any agency thereof to perform a duty . . . .” 
28 Defendants are all state and local officials, so Section 1361 does not apply.  Moreover, it is an
4

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 46   Filed 06/02/16   Page 5 of 7
1 abuse of discretion for a district court to issue an injunction that requires state officials to do
2 anything more than what is required by federal constitutional or statutory law.  See Trueblood v.
3 Washington State Dept. of Soc. and Health Services, No. 15-35462, 2016 WL 2610233, at *7
4 (9th Cir. May 6, 2016) (citing Katie A., ex rel. Ludin v. Los Angeles Cnty., 481 F.3d 1150, 1155
5 (9th Cir. 2007)). 
6 Plaintiffs’ delay in bringing this motion has left too little time for any relief anyway,
7 save and except for possibly relief at polling places.  Contrary to plaintiffs, however, state law
8 does not require defendants to affirmatively inform no-party-preference voters of their rights to
9 obtain a crossover ballot at the polling place.  Section 13102(b) of the California Elections Code
10 provides, “[a]t partisan primary elections, each voter not registered disclosing a preference with
t 11 any one of the political parties participating in an election shall be furnished only a nonpartisan
r
u
o a 12 ballot, unless he or she requests a ballot of a political party” that has authorized crossover
C ni
  or
ct alif 13 ballots.  Thus, the plain language of the statute contemplates that the voter would affirmatively
i C
tr of 
Dis strict  14 request the crossover ballot.
  Di
tates orthern  15 As stated, the Court is without jurisdiction to issue an injunction against our defendants
S N 16 based on a state law duty, but plaintiffs have not shown that they could succeed on the merits in
ted  For the  17 any case.
i
n
U
18 2. NO IRREPARABLE HARM.
19 Plaintiffs’ theory of harm rests entirely on speculation.  They contend no-party-
20 preference voters might be denied crossover ballots or might be unaware of their rights, and
21 they are concerned that defendants will act contrary to the law although there is no factual basis
22 for that concern.  Defendants have already undertaken significant efforts to inform voters,
23 particularly no-party-preference voters, of their rights, and voters will have additional
24 information in front of them at their respective polling places.  Far from establishing irreparable
25 harm might occur, plaintiffs have failed to show that they would suffer any harm as a result of a
26 denial of their motion.   
27 3. BALANCE OF THE EQUITIES AND PUBLIC INTEREST.
28 In Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, 585 (1964), the Supreme Court cautioned:
5

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 46   Filed 06/02/16   Page 6 of 7
1 [U]nder certain circumstances, such as where an impending
election is imminent and a State’s election machinery is already in
2 progress, equitable considerations might justify a court in
withholding the granting of immediately effective relief in a
3 legislative apportionment case, even though the existing
apportionment scheme was found invalid.  In awarding or
4 withholding immediate relief, a court is entitled to and should
consider the proximity of a forthcoming election and the
5 mechanics and complexities of state election laws, and should act
and rely upon general equitable principles.  With respect to the
6 timing of relief, a court can reasonably endeavor to avoid a
disruption of the election process which might result from
7 requiring precipitate changes that could make unreasonable or
embarrassing demands on a State in adjusting to the requirements
8 of the court’s decree.
9 In S.W. Voter Registration Educ. Project v. Shelley, 344 F.3d 914, 919 (9th Cir. 2003), our
10 court of appeals applied the same principle in the context of an injunction in a Voting Rights
t 11 Act case (as here):
r
u
o a 12 In this case, hardship falls not only upon the putative defendant,
C ni
  or the California Secretary of State, but on all the citizens of
ct alif 13 California, because this case concerns a statewide election.  The
i C
tr of  public interest is significantly affected.  For this reason our law
 Dis District  14 rinecjuongcntiizoens  ctahsaet se. lSeeceti,o en. gc.a, sReesy anroel ddsif fve. rSeinmt sf,r o3m77 o Urd.Sin. aarty 585, 84
tates orthern  15 Sex.Ctrta.o 1r3d6in2a. r yIn, tiedr.f, earnedn cien tweriftehr eimncpee nwdiitnhg a nel eecleticotinosn i safter voting
S N 16 has begun is unprecedented.
ted  For the  17 Although plaintiffs became aware of many of the alleged irregularities and inaccuracies
i
n
U
18 herein at least as early as May 13, they did not file this motion until 7:00 p.m. on Friday, May
19 27, just eleven days before the election.  Moreover, although the Court set a briefing and
20 hearing schedule just three minutes after the motion was filed, plaintiffs’ delays ensured that the
21 motion could not be heard and decided until June 1, less than a week before the primary. 
22 Plaintiffs’ proposed relief, to the extent it is feasible at all, would no doubt cause voter
23 confusion by changing the rules in the middle of the primary and changing the messaging about
24 voters’ rights.  Voters have already received clear enough instructions, submitted their vote-by-
25 mail applications, and some votes have already been cast.  The extraordinary remedy that
26 plaintiffs seek is not warranted.
27 Plaintiffs’ contention that they could not file the complaint or this motion because they
28 were developing their theory based on poll-worker training rings hollow.  Plaintiffs should have
6

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 46   Filed 06/02/16   Page 7 of 7
1 been investigating that issue from the outset, and they should have sought relief as to the claims
2 they already knew about immediately.  Moreover, plaintiffs delayed more than twenty-four
3 hours between informing the deputy courtroom clerk that they would seek to be heard on a
4 request to shorten time to hear this motion and actually filing this motion. 
5 CONCLUSION 
6 The reasons stated above required denial of plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary
7 injunction.
8
9 Dated:   June 2, 2016.                                                                
WILLIAM ALSUP
10 UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE

MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES 
1 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
2 
3  As the Court concluded three weeks ago in its Order denying Plaintiff’s motion for a 
4  preliminary injunction, Plaintiffs’ assertion that the San Francisco Department of Elections 
5  (“Department”) has violated their voting rights is entirely meritless.  Like Plaintiffs’ motion for 
6  preliminary injunction, the Complaint alleges that the Department has violated the Constitution, the 
7  Voting Rights Act, and California law by failing to inform voters who have not expressed a party 
8  preference (“No Party Preference” or “NPP” voters) that they can vote in the Democratic, Libertarian, 
9  or American Independent presidential primaries on the June 7, 2016 election, and by failing to inform 
10  voters who have expressed a party preference that they can change that preference.  On June 2, 2016, 
11  the Court rejected every single one of Plaintiffs’ legal theories.  (Docket No. 46 (“Order”).)  In the 
12  intervening three weeks, only one thing has changed:  in addition to failing to state a claim, the case is 
13  now moot because the election has already occurred and the alleged “injury” of the two registered San 
14  Francisco voter Plaintiffs has been resolved because they actually did vote in the Democratic Party 
15  primary. 
II.  THE PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY ELECTION ON JUNE 7, 2016 
16 
17  Each political party has the option of allowing NPP voters to vote in its presidential primary.  
18  For the June 7 election, three political parties chose to do so: the Democratic Party, the American 
19  Independent Party, and the Libertarian Party.  Compl. ¶ 3.1  An NPP voter who votes in one of these 
20  primaries does so using what is sometimes called a “crossover ballot.”  See id. 
21  A voter who wishes to vote by mail must apply to do so.  See Cal. Elections Code § 3001.  A 
22  voter may apply to receive a vote-by-mail ballot at every election or may apply to receive such a ballot 
23  only for a specific election.  See id. §§ 3201; 3006(a)(4).  If a county elections official chooses to mail 
24  a vote-by-mail application to registered voters, that application must contain certain information, such 
25  as the date by which the application is due, space for the voter’s name, address, and signature, as well 
26  as the name and date for which the request to vote by mail is made.  See id., § 3006(a); see also id. § 
27

2  application must inform the voters that they can vote in a presidential primary for any party that has 
3  opened its primary to NPP voters.  See id. § 3006(c).  That application must also include the following 
4  statement: “I have declined to disclose a preference for a qualified political party. However, for this 
5  primary election only, I request a vote by mail ballot for the _________ Party.”  Id.

17

2.  Second Cause of Action: Voting Rights Act—52 U.S.C. § 10101(B) 
1 
2  According to the Complaint, “[c]ertain Plaintiffs – or the individuals that they represent – are 
3  in imminent danger of being denied the right to vote in the Presidential primary election because of the 
4  errors and omissions contained in the mandatory notices containing crucial information necessary in 
5  order to obtain the ballot.  These errors or omissions are not material in determining whether these 
6  individuals are qualified under State law to vote in the June 2016 Presidential primary election.”  See 
7  id. ¶ 27.  There are two alleged “errors or omissions” identified in the Complaint.  See id. ¶¶ 8-11. 
8  The first is on the Department’s online vote-by-mail application, which, according to the 
9  Complaint, does not provide to all voters the statement in Elections Code Section 3006(c)—“I have 
10  declined to disclose a preference for a qualified political party.”  In other words, Plaintiffs allege that 
11  the Department violated the Voting Rights Act by failing to tell voters who have disclosed a 
12  preference for a qualified political party that that they “have declined to disclose a preference for a 
13  qualified political party.”  Compl. ¶ 8.  The second alleged omission is similar to the first.  The 
14  Complaint alleges that the back cover of the VIP should have informed all voters, including those who 
15  have disclosed a preference for a qualified political party that that they “have declined to disclose a 
16  preference for a qualified political party.”  See id. ¶ 9. 
3.  Third Cause of Action: First and Fourteenth Amendments 
17 
18  Plaintiffs allege that the Department violated the Constitution by arbitrarily discriminating 
19  between NPP and non-NPP voters.  See id. ¶ 29.  This alleged discrimination appears to consist of 
20  allegedly not informing NPP voters that they can obtain a crossover ballot and allegedly not informing 
21  party preference voters that they can change party preference.  See id. ¶ 3-5, 9-10.

22

24  33-34.  The state laws listed in the Complaint are Elections Code § 3006(c) (requiring mailers to NPP 
25  voters who have registered to vote by mail include a crossover ballot request form); Elections Code § 
26  3007.7(e) (requiring online vote-by-mail applications to inform NPP voters that they can request a 
27  crossover ballot); and Elections Code § 3006(b)(3) (requiring that vote-by-mail application forms tell 
28  voters that they can hand deliver the application to the county elections official).  Compl. ¶ 7-11.

C.  The Remedies Sought 
1 
2    The Complaint seeks 11 specific remedies.  Eight of those remedies (Prayers 2-9) seek court 
3  orders to prevent certain harms from occurring at the June 7 election.  Specifically, Plaintiffs seek 
4  orders requiring the Department to: provide certain information to voters (Prayer 2); have enough 
5  ballots (Prayer 3); allow NPP voters to obtain a crossover ballot when voting at a polling (Prayer 4); 
6  change its website so voters know they can obtain crossover ballots (Prayer 5); allow NPP voters to 
7  write-in the names of presidential primary candidates (Prayer 6); extend the voter registration deadline 
8  to allow voters to change party preference (Prayer 7); inform party preference voters that they can 
9  switch to NPP (Prayer 8); and issue provisional ballots only if there is no other option (Prayer 9).  The 
10  other three remedies sought are declaratory relief (Prayer 1); fees (Prayer 10); and costs (Prayer 11). 
V.  PROCEDURAL HISTORY 
11 
12  Plaintiffs filed their complaint on May 20, 2016, and amended it the same day.  (Docket No. 1; 
13  2.)  Plaintiffs then waited a week to file their motion for preliminary injunction.  (Docket Nos. 12-14, 
14  16-17.)  The Department first appeared in this action on May 31, 2016, opposing Plaintiffs’ 
15  preliminary injunction motion.  (Docket No. 32.)  On June 1, 2016, the Court held a hearing on 
16  Plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction, and denied that motion from the bench.  (Docket No. 47.)  
17  The next day, the Court issued an Order setting forth its reasoning for denying the motion.  (Docket 
18  No. 46.)  Despite multiple requests from defense counsel, Plaintiffs have refused to dismiss their 
19  lawsuit.   
VI.  LEGAL STANDARD 
20 
21  A court may dismiss a complaint for failure to state a claim under Federal Rule of Civil 
22  Procedure 12(b)(6) when “it is clear that no relief could be granted under any set of facts that could be 
23  proven consistent with the allegations.”  Hishon v. King & Spalding, 467 U.S. 69, 73 (1984).  
24  Dismissal is also proper where the complaint alleges facts that demonstrate that the complaint is barred 
25  as a matter of law.  See Balistreri v. Pacifica Police Dept., 901 F.2d 696, 699 (9th Cir. 1990); Jablon 
26  v. Dean Witter & Co., 614 F.2d 677, 682 (9th Cir. 1980).  To survive a motion to dismiss, a complaint 
27  must state a claim that is facially plausible, that is, “‘the non-conclusory factual content,’ and 
28 
S.F. Dept. of Elections’ Mot. to Dismiss  7 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01114811.docx
CASE NO.  C16-2739 WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 51   Filed 06/20/16   Page 14 of 21
 
1  reasonable inferences from that content, must be plausibly suggestive of a claim entitling the Plaintiff 
2  to relief.”  Moss v. U.S. Secret Serv., 572 F.3d 962, 969 (9th Cir. 2009).   
3  VII.  ARGUMENT 
A.  This Lawsuit Is Moot Because the Election Has Already Occurred.4 
4 
5  “It is the inexorable command of the United States Constitution that the federal courts confine 
6  themselves to actual cases and controversies. See U.S. CONST. art III, § 2, cl. 1.”  Gator.com Corp. v. 
7  L.L. Bean, Inc., 398 F.3d 1125, 1128 (9th Cir. 2005).  Article III requires that an actual controversy 
8  exist at all phases of the litigation. Protectmarriage.com-Yes on 8 v. Brown, 752 F.3d 827, 834 (9th 
9  Cir. 2014); Gator.com, 398 F.3d at 1128.  Thus, moot claims are not justiciable.  The court “loses its 
10  power to render a decision on the merits of a claim [citation], when [it] can no longer effectively 
11  remedy a ‘present controversy’ between the parties.”  Protectmarriage.com, 752 F.3d at 834.   
12  Plaintiffs’ claims are now moot because the primary election was concluded June 7.  All of 
13  Plaintiffs’ allegations are based on events relating to that election.  Compl. ¶¶ 4-5, 7-14, 16, 18-19.  
14  Plaintiffs’ alleged injuries and the relief they seek are specific to the election.  There is no justiciable 
15  controversy because the Court is “unable to effectively remedy a present controversy between the 
16  parties where a plaintiff seeks to enjoin an activity that has already occurred, and [the court] cannot 
17  ‘undo’ that action’s allegedly harmful effects.”  Protectmarriage.com, 752 F.3d at 834. 
18 
B.  Plaintiffs Lack Standing Because Their Injuries Have Always Been Speculative, 
and In Any Event, the Action Is Moot Because Both Plaintiffs Who Have Any 
19 
Alleged Connection to San Francisco Voted in the Democratic Presidential 
Primary. 
20 
21  Article III requires a plaintiff in federal court to have standing.  Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 
22  504 U.S. 555, 561 (1992) (describing standing as “an irreducible constitutional minimum”).  To 
23  establish standing, Plaintiffs must show that: (1) they suffered an injury in fact – an invasion of a 
24  legally protected interest that is (a) concrete and particularized, and (b) actual or imminent, not 
25  conjectural or hypothetical; (2) there is a causal connection between the injury and the conduct 
26  complained of; and (3) it is likely, as opposed to merely speculative, that the injury will be redressed 
27                                                   
4 The two paragraphs in this section are largely identical to those in the Secretary of State’s 
28  motion to dismiss, Docket No. 48 at 6. 
S.F. Dept. of Elections’ Mot. to Dismiss  8 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01114811.docx
CASE NO.  C16-2739 WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 51   Filed 06/20/16   Page 15 of 21
 
1  by a favorable decision.  Id. at 560-61 (citations and quotations marks omitted).  Where an allegation 
2  of injury is conjectural or hypothetical and not clean-cut and concrete, concepts of standing and 
3  ripeness overlap and provide additional ground for dismissing a complaint.  Wolfson v. Brammer, 616 
4  F.3d 1045, 1058 (9th Cir. 2010).   
5  Here, the two plaintiffs alleged to have any connection to San Francisco are Suzanne Bushnell 
6  and Clara Daims.  The Complaint alleges that Ms. Bushnell, who is a Democrat, was “uncertain” 
7  whether she would be able to obtain a Democratic ballot if she became an NPP voter.  Compl. ¶ 18.  
8  Not only is this “injury” pure speculation, it is also absurd—if Ms. Bushnell wanted to vote in the 
9  Democatic primary, she could have simply remained a Democrat, received her ballot, and voted.  
10  Equally speculative is the “injury” of Ms. Daims, an NPP voter who was “uncertain” whether she 
11  would be able to vote in the Democratic primary.  Compl. ¶ 19.  But this is not a concrete injury either:  
12  if Ms. Daims wished to determine whether she could vote in the Democratic primary, all she had to do 
13  was inform the Department of Elections that she wanted to vote in the Democratic primary.  Indeed, as 
14  discussed in the next paragraph and footnote 5, she did just that. 
15  These “injuries” are so speculative and baseless that they never satisfied Article III standing 
16  requirements.  And even if they ever met that standard, they no longer do.  Ms. Daims and Ms. 
17  Bushnell both voted in the Democratic primary, Arntz Dec. ¶ 5,5 and as such, their claims are moot.  
18  See Protectmarriage.com-Yes on 8, 752 F.3d at 834.6  
19 
20 
                                                 
5 The Department requests that the Court take judicial notice of the fact that Ms. Daims and 
21 
Ms. Bushnell voted in the Democratic presidential primary at the June 7, 2016 election.  Courts may 
take judicial notice of facts as part of a motion to dismiss.  See In re Northpoint Communications 
22 
Group, Inc., Securities Litigation, 221 F.Supp.2d at 1094.  “A judicially noticed fact must be one not 
subject to reasonable dispute in that it is . . . capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to 
23 
sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned.”  Fed. R. Evid. 201(b).  As described in 
Director Arntz’s declaration, the Department maintains a registration database, which includes each 
24 
voter’s voting history.  Arntz Dec. ¶ 4.  Director Arntz checked that database on June 16, 2016 and 
observed that both Ms. Daims and Ms. Bushnell cast votes in the Democratic presidential primary for 
25 
the June 7, 2016 election.  See id.   
26  6 The Complaint does not allege that the other two Defendants—the Voting Rights Defense 
Project and the American Independent Party—suffered any injury.  Even if the Complaint did allege 
27  that those Defendants were “injured” by the alleged confusion of NPP voters as to which primary they 
could vote in, those alleged injuries would be just as speculative as those alleged by Ms. Daims and 
28  Ms. Bushnell. 
S.F. Dept. of Elections’ Mot. to Dismiss  9 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01114811.docx
CASE NO.  C16-2739 WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 51   Filed 06/20/16   Page 16 of 21
 
C.  The Causes of Action Fail to State a Claim. 
1 
1.  Plaintiffs’ Voting Rights Act Claim Under Section 10101(a)(2)(A) Fails 
Because Voter Registration Is Not At Issue in This Case. 
2 
3  Plaintiffs allege that the Department violated 52 U.S.C. § 10101(a)(2)(A), which states: 
No person acting under color of law shall in determining whether any individual 
4 
is qualified under State law or laws to vote in any election, apply any standard, 
practice, or procedure different from the standards, practices, or procedures 
5 
applied under such law or laws to other individuals within the same county, 
parish, or similar political subdivision who have been found by State officials to 
6 
be qualified to vote. . . . 
7 
That provision “was designed to eliminate practices that could encumber an individual’s ability 
8 
to register to vote.”  Friedman v. Snipes, 345 F.Supp.2d 1356, 1371 (S.D. Fla. 2004) (citing Schwier v. 
9 
Cox, 340 F.3d 1284, 1297 (11th Cir. 2003).  As this Court has already held: “Section 10101(a)(2)(A) 
10 
concerns voter registration, which is not at issue here.”  Order at 4.   
11 
2.  Plaintiffs’ Voting Rights Act Claim Under Section 10101(a)(2)(B) Fails 
Because The Complaint Fails to Allege a Legally Cognizable Error or 
12 
Omission on Any Writing Requisite to Voting. 
13 
Plaintiffs’ claim under Subsection (B)—sometimes referred to as the Voting Rights Act’s 
14 
“materiality provision”—is equally meritless.  Originally enacted as part of the Civil Rights Act of 
15 
1964, Subsection (B) was a piece of the federal government’s effort to enforce voting rights and 
16 
“counteract state and local government tactics of using, among other things, burdensome registration 
17 
requirements to disenfranchise African-Americans.”  Florida State Conference of N.A.A.C.P. v. 
18 
Browning, 522 F.3d 1153, 1173 (11th Cir. 2008).   Subsection (B) states: 
19  No person acting under color of law may deny the right of any individual to 
vote in any election because of an error or omission on any record or paper 
20  relating to any application, registration, or other act requisite to voting, if such 
error or omission is not material in determining whether such individual is 
21  qualified under State law to vote in such election. 
22 
Plaintiffs’ Section (B) claim fails because there has been no “error or omission.”  The alleged 
23 
omission described in the Complaint is the Department’s failure to tell voters who have disclosed a 
24 
preference for a qualified political party that that they have not “disclose[d] a preference for a 
25 
qualified political party.”  This does not constitute a legally cognizable error or omission within the 
26 
meaning of the Voting Rights Act because registrars have no legal obligation to make this disclosure, 
27 
and indeed, doing so would confuse voters.  In addition, the alleged error or omission does not occur 
28 
S.F. Dept. of Elections’ Mot. to Dismiss  10 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01114811.docx
CASE NO.  C16-2739 WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 51   Filed 06/20/16   Page 17 of 21
 
1  on an “application, registration, or other act requisite to voting.”  This is because people requesting 
2  crossover ballots have already registered to vote.  As the Secretary of State argues in support of his 
3  motion to dismiss, there is no allegation that the Department rejected any application to register to vote 
4  or attempt to vote.  (Docket No. 48 at 11.) 
5  The Complaint appears to allege that the Department erred within the meaning of Subsection 
6  (B) by failing to tell party preference voters that they can re-register as NPP voters.  Compl. ¶ 3.  Not 
7  only is this supposed error nonsensical—if a party preference voter didn’t want to vote in the party’s 
8  primary, they could simply choose not to vote in that primary—but Plaintiffs lack standing to assert 
9  this error since they both allege that they wanted to vote in the Democratic primary.  Compl. ¶¶ 18-19. 
3.  Plaintiffs’ First and Fourteenth Amendment Claim Fails Because The 
10 
Department Has Not Burdened Voting Rights. 
11 
The Complaint alleges that the Department violated the First Amendment and the Fourteenth 
12 
Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause.  To assess the constitutionality of election laws, courts apply a 
13 
“flexible standard” that weighs the burdens of such regulation against the government’s interests in 
14 
enacting those laws.  Burdick v. Takushi, 504 U.S. 428, 434 (1992).  Focusing on “the extent to which 
15 
a challenged regulation burdens First and Fourteenth Amendments rights,” the Court has applied the 
16 
following test:   
17 
 . . . when those rights are subjected to severe restrictions, the regulation must be 
narrowly drawn to advance a state interest of compelling importance.  But when 
18 
a state election law provision imposes only reasonable, nondiscriminatory 
restrictions upon the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights of voters, the 
19 
State’s important regulatory interests are generally sufficient to justify the 
restrictions. 
20 
21  Id. at 434 (quotations and citations omitted).  If the burden is severe, the regulation is subject to strict 
22  scrutiny; if the challenged regulation is reasonable and nondiscriminatory, it may be justified by 
23  important regulatory interests.  The Supreme Court and the Ninth Circuit have consistently applied this 
24  balancing approach in considering First Amendment, Due Process, and Equal Protection challenges to 
25  election laws.  See Dudum v. Arntz, 640 F.3d 1098, 1106 n.15 (9th Cir. 2011); Lemons v. Bradbury, 
26  538 F.3d 1098, 1103 (9th Cir. 2008).  Courts have occasionally described the test for reasonable, 
27  nondiscriminatory regulations as a “rational basis” test, Libertarian Party of Washington v. Munro, 31 
28  F.3d 759, 761 (9th Cir. 1994), under which a plaintiff must demonstrate that the challenged regulation 
S.F. Dept. of Elections’ Mot. to Dismiss  11 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01114811.docx
CASE NO.  C16-2739 WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 51   Filed 06/20/16   Page 18 of 21
 
1  is “not rationally related to a legitimate state interest.”  Arizona Libertarian Party v. Reagan, 798 F.3d 
2  723, 733-34 (9th Cir. 2015).   
3  Applying this standard, the courts have upheld a myriad of election regulations as reasonable 
4  and non-discriminatory, even where there is a significant possibility that they would burden voters.  
5  See, e.g., Crawford v. Marion County Election Board, 553 U.S. 181, 185, 202-03 (2008) (plurality 
6  opinion) (voter identification); Rosario v. Rockefeller, 410 U.S. 752, 760-62 (1973) (advance 
7  enrollment requirement for party primary elections); Burns v. Fortson, 410 U.S. 686, 686-87 (1973) 
8  (requirement that voters register at least 50 days prior to election); Marston v. Lewis, 410 U.S. 679, 
9  680-81 (1973) (requirement that voters reside in jurisdiction for 50 days prior to registration); see also 
10  Ayers-Schaffner v. DiStefano, 37 F.3d 726, 729 n.8 (1st Cir. 1994) (“It is, of course, well established 
11  that states may restrict the voting privilege through residency and other requirements.”).   
12  Plaintiffs’ constitutional claims fail for the reasons already articulated by the Court: “Here, the 
13  burden on no-party-preference voters, is slight, if it exists at all.  Voters must read the materials 
14  provided to them to understand their rights; only some counties will spoonfeed the information.  The 
15  government’s interests in arranging for an orderly and fair primary, avoiding voter confusion by 
16  providing too much information, and ensuring that voters can receive their ballots in a timely manner 
17  all plainly justify defendants’ conduct.”  Order at 4.   
18  This ruling is equally applicable in the context of a motion to dismiss.  The Complaint 
19  incorporates by reference the Voter Information Pamphlet which, among other things, clearly explains 
20  all of the relevant issues in this case, including informing NPP voters that they can obtain a crossover 
21  ballot for one of three primaries and informing party preference voters of their right to change their 
22  party preference.  As a matter of law, there was no burden on NPP voters or any other voters.  The 
23  Department’s decision to provide this information to voters—and to not provide the additional, 
24  irrelevant information that Plaintiffs demand—was motivated by the legitimate goal of avoiding voter 
25  confusion.  Similarly, the Department’s online vote-by-mail application did not burden voting rights 
26  and was justified by a reasonable governmental interest.  The Department appropriately declined to tell 
27  party preference voters that they had not disclosed a party preference.  This decision avoided 
28  confusion and, far from burdening voting rights, helped realize them. 
S.F. Dept. of Elections’ Mot. to Dismiss  12 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01114811.docx
CASE NO.  C16-2739 WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 51   Filed 06/20/16   Page 19 of 21
 
1    At a more general level, there are no cases of which the Department is aware holding that an 
2  elections official violates the First or Fourteenth Amendments by failing to provide all voters with 
3  identical information.  In support of their preliminary injunction motion, Plaintiffs relied exclusively 
4  on one case—Griffin v. Burns, 431 F.Supp. 1361, 1363 (Dist. of R.I., May 17, 1977)—but that case is 
5  not even remotely apposite.  There, the plaintiffs were absentee voters whose ballots had been rejected 
6  following a ruling by the Rhode Island Supreme Court that “there is no constitutional or statutory basis 
7  for allowing absentee and shut-in voters to cast their votes in a primary election.”  Id. (quoting 
8  McCormick v. State Board of Elections, 374 A.2d 116 (R.I. 1977)).  The district court held that 
9  categorically rejecting absentee ballots while accepting ballots cast at the polling place violated the 
10  Equal Protection Clause.  Id.  This case is nothing like Griffin.  The Department has complied fully 
11  with the law, has appropriately informed voters of their rights, and has not categorically rejected vote-
12  by-mail ballots.   
4.  Plaintiffs’ Request for a Writ of Mandamus Fails for Multiple Reasons. 
13 
14  The Court has already ruled that Plaintiffs’ claim for a writ of mandamus is meritless, and the 
15  Court’s reasoning is equally applicable here:  “Plaintiffs do not assert independent claims based on 
16  violations of state law but rather seek a writ of mandamus under federal law compelling defendants to 
17  carry out certain alleged duties under state law.  Plaintiffs cite Section 1361 of Title 28 of the United 
18  States Code as the authority for that relief, but that provision only grants a district court authority to 
19  compel ‘an officer or employee of the United States or any agency thereof to perform a duty . . . .’  
20  Defendants are all state and local officials, so Section 1361 does not apply.”  Order at 4.   
21  The Court’s ruling is consisent with applicable caselaw.  “[F]ederal district courts are without 
22  power to issue mandamus to direct state courts, state judicial officers, or other state officials in the 
23  performance of their duties.  A petition for a writ of mandamus to compel a state court or official to 
24  take or refrain from some action is frivolous as a matter of law.”  Todd v. McElhany, No. CIV S-11-
25  2346 LKK, 2011 WL 5526464, at *2 (E.D. Cal. Nov. 14, 2011) (citing, inter alia, Demos v. U.S. 
26  District Court, 925 F.2d 1160, 1161 (9th Cir. 1991), and Clark v. Washington, 366 F.2d 678, 681 (9th 
27  Cir.1966)); Barber v. Beard, 2015 WL 506254, at *6 (S.D. Cal., Feb. 5, 2015) (“But under the plain 
28  language of [28 U.S.C. § 1361], federal district courts do not have mandamus jurisdiction over state 
S.F. Dept. of Elections’ Mot. to Dismiss  13 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01114811.docx
CASE NO.  C16-2739 WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 51   Filed 06/20/16   Page 20 of 21
 
1  officials.”); Ciacci v. Hawaii Government, 2012 WL 6697569, at *2 (D. Hawaii, Dec. 24, 2012) (“28 
2  U.S.C. § 1361 provides district courts with jurisdiction in the nature of mandamus to compel officers 
3  or employees of the United States—not state agencies or actors like those named as Defendants in this 
4  action—to perform a duty owed to a plaintiff.”); Newton v. Poindexter, 578 F.Supp. 277, 279 (E.D. 
5  Cal., Jan. 18, 1984) (holding that federal courts cannot compel action by state officials under 28 
6  U.S.C. § 1361).  
7  There is an additional reason that Plaintiffs’ claim under Section 1361 fails.  As this Court held 
8  in its Order denying Plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction: “[I]t is an abuse of discretion for a 
9  district court to issue an injunction that requires state officials to do anything more than what is 
10  required by federal constitutional or statutory law.  See Trueblood v. Washington State Dept. of Soc. 
11  and Health Services, No. 15-35462, 2016 WL 2610233, at *7 (9th Cir. May 6, 2016) (citing Katie A., 
12  ex rel. Ludin v. Los Angeles Cnty., 481 F.3d 1150, 1155 (9th Cir. 2007)).”  Order at 4-5.  That 
13  authority is equally applicable in the context of a Rule 12(b)(6) motion. 
14  Even if the Court could reach the merits of Plaintiffs’ state law claims, they are meritless.  
15  First, according to Plaintiffs, the Department’s online vote-by-mail application feature violates 
16  Elections Code Sections 3006(c) and 3007.7(e) by failing to tell party preference voters that they have 
17  not disclosed a party preference (despite the fact that they have, in fact, disclosed a party preference). 
18  Plaintiffs’ argument ignores the fact that the Department’s online vote-by-mail application feature is 
19  two-step process, and though the first page does not include the language from Section 3006(c), the 
20  second page does.  As described above, once a voter inputs his or her house number, zip code, and 
21  date of birth, the website determines whether that person is an NPP voter.  Arntz Dec. ¶ 2, Ex. A.  If 
22  so, the next page provides the voter with the information required by Section 3006(c) and includes a 
23  link to a vote-by-mail application that includes the language required by Section 3006(c).  See id. ¶ 2, 
24  Ex. B-C.   
25  Second, the Complaint alleges that the Department violated Elections Code Section 3006 
26  because the back cover of the VIP sent to NPP voters contains the Section 3006(c) language but the 
27  back cover of the VIP sent to party preference voters does not.  But again, it is not reasonable to 
28  construe Section 3006(c) to mean that voters who have disclosed a preference for a qualified political 
S.F. Dept. of Elections’ Mot. to Dismiss  14 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01114811.docx
CASE NO.  C16-2739 WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 51   Filed 06/20/16   Page 21 of 21
 
1  party must receive a statement saying: “I have declined to disclose a preference for a qualified political 
2  party.”   
3  Third, the Complaint alleges that the Department has not properly notified people registering to 
4  vote by mail that they may personally deliver their application to the Department in City Hall.  But 
when an NPP voter fills out an application to vote by mail on the Department’s website, the website 
5 
states: “You may mail, deliver or fax the form to the address or fax number listed on the application.”  
6 
Arntz Dec., Ex. B (emphasis added).  In addition, the application itself states, “Deliver, mail, or fax the 
7 
completed application to the address or fax number listed below.”  See id., Ex. C.7  (emphasis added).  
8 
That documents can be hand delivered to the Department is also included throughout the VIP.  See id., 
9 
Ex. D. 
10 
Finally, to the extent Plaintiffs claim that the Department violated state law by not offering 
11 
crossover ballots to NPP voters, this claim fails because, as the Court has already ruled: “Contrary to 
12 
plaintiffs, however, state law does not require defendants to affirmatively inform no-party-preference 
13 
voters of their rights to obtain a crossover ballot at the polling place.  Section 13102(b) of the 
14 
California Elections Code provides, ‘[a]t partisan primary elections, each voter not registered 
15 
disclosing a preference with any one of the political parties participating in an election shall be 
16 
furnished only a nonpartisan ballot, unless he or she requests a ballot of a political party’ that has 
17 
authorized crossover ballots.  Thus, the plain language of the statute contemplates that the voter would 
18 
affirmatively request the crossover ballot.”  Order at 5. 
19  CONCLUSION 
For the foregoing reasons, the Court should grant the motion to dismiss without leave to 
20 
amend, as the flaws described above are fatal and cannot be cured through amendment. 
21 
Dated:  June 20, 2016       By:  /s/Joshua S. White   
22 
JOSHUA S. WHITE, Attorneys for JOHN ARNTZ 
23 
                                                 
7 As noted above, the Complaint contains a link to the Department’s online vote-by-mail 
24 
application.  Compl. ¶ 8.  For NPP voters, the second page of that application (which appears after 
they have entered their house number, zip code, and date of birth) includes a link to a form to request a 
25 
crossover ballot.  Arntz Dec. ¶ 2; Ex. B, C.  The Court should consider this form as part of the instant 
motion to dismiss both because it is referenced in the Complaint (in paragraphs 8 and 11), and because 
26 
it satisfies the standard for a judicially noticeable document under Federal Rule of Evidence 201(b).  
The contents of the form are not subject to reasonable dispute and they are capable of accurate and 
27 
ready determination simply looking at the website.  Arntz Dec. ¶ 2; Ex. B, C.   
28

Case No.  CV-16-2739 WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 35   Filed 05/31/16   Page 2 of 13
 
1  I, John Arntz, declare as follows: 
2  1.  I am San Francisco’s Director of Elections, and I am a named defendant in this action.  
3  I have personal knowledge of the following facts, except those stated on information and belief.  As to 
4  those facts, I believe them to be true.  If called upon to testify, I could and would testify competently 
5  to the contents of this Declaration. 
6  2.  I am the head of San Francisco’s Department of Elections (“Department”).  The 
7  Department conducts all federal, state and local elections in San Francisco.  Serving nearly 467,000 
8  registered voters, the Department must ensure that the City meets all applicable legal deadlines, that it 
9  has adequate staff and equipment to provide election services, that the recording and tabulation of 
10  votes is accurate and secure, and that voting equipment and polling places are usable and accessible to 
11  voters.  For the presidential primary election on June 7, 2016, the Department has hired approximately 
12  250 temporary employees, including more than 30 dedicated to voter services and outreach.  On 
13  Election Day, the Department will manage 576 polling places staffed by 2,500 volunteer poll workers.   
14  3.  Federal, state and local law closely regulate and prescribe nearly every aspect of the 
15  Department’s operations to ensure that San Francisco’s elections are fair and functional.  In 
16  compliance with these laws, the Department must adhere to a strict schedule to complete essential 
17  tasks for each election, including: ordering ballot supplies; preparing and printing ballots; mailing 
18  overseas and other vote-by-mail (formerly known as absentee) ballots; printing and distributing 
19  information to the voters; training employees and poll workers; testing the accuracy of every voting 
20  machine that will be used in the election; counting and tabulating votes; and conducting a mandatory 
21  post-election hand count to verify election results.  
22   
23  The Presidential Primary Election on June 7, 2016 
24  4.  When registering to vote in California, a person has the option of selecting a political 
25  party preference.  Voters who register to vote without stating a party preference are known as “No 
26  Party Preference” or NPP voters.  Each political party has the option of allowing NPP voters to vote in 
27  its presidential primary.  For California’s presidential primary election on June 7, 2016, three political 
28 
Dec. of San Francisco Director of Elections John Arntz  1 n:\ethics\li2016\161255\01109907.docx
Case No.  CV-16-2739 WHA 
 

Case 3:16-cv-02739-WHA   Document 35   Filed 05/31/16   Page 3 of 13
 
1  parties have chosen to allow NPP voters to vote on their presidential primary ballot:  the Democratic 
2  Party, the American Independent Party, and the Libertarian Party. 
3  5.  To obtain a vote-by-mail ballot, a person must apply by filling out an application and 
4  transmitting it to the Department by the seventh day prior to the election.  Cal. Elections Code § 3001.  
5  For the June 7 election, that deadline is May 31.   
6   
7  The Department Has Made Extensive Efforts to Inform NPP Voters That They May Vote in a 
8  Presidential Primary. 
9  6.  The Department has made extensive efforts to inform NPP voters—both those who 
10  have applied to vote by mail and those who will be voting in-person at a polling place—that they may 
11  vote in one of the three presidential primaries.     
12  7.  First, the Department has sent a mailer to all NPP voters who have applied to vote by 
13  mail informing them that they may request a “cross-over ballot,” i.e., a ballot that allows them to vote 
14  in a presidential primary in the June election.  A true and correct copy of such a mailer is attached 
15  hereto as Exhibit A.  Each mailer includes an application that allows NPP voters to request a vote-by-
16  mail ballot for one of the three political parties.  The Department processes all applications received 
17  even after the deadline indicated on the mailer.  
18  8.  Second, the Department includes a detailed “Voting Instructions” guide with every 
19  vote-by-mail ballot sent to San Francisco voters.  A true and correct copy of a “Voting Instructions” 
20  guide is attached hereto as Exhibit B.  An NPP voter may then request a replacement ballot that 
21  includes a presidential primary ballot.  The guide includes a link to the Department’s website where 
22  the voter can request a replacement ballot.  A copy of the replacement ballot form is attached hereto as 
23  Exhibit C.   
24  9.  Third, in early May 2016, the Department provided a Voter Information Pamphlet 
25  (“VIP”) to every registered San Francisco voter in either hard copy or digital format.  In addition, the 
26  Department mails VIPs to people who register to vote after the VIPs have been mailed.  The VIP is

1  also available online, in multiple languages.1  Though the substance of the VIP is the same for all

5  ballot for the presidential primary indicated on the application.  Attached hereto as Exhibit D is a true

7  correct copy of the back cover of a VIP that a non-NPP voter would receive.  The Department’s goal is 
8  to write the VIP at an eighth grade reading level.   
9  10.  Fourth, the Department’s website offers voters an online tool to look up their voter 
10  registration status.2  An NPP voter who looks up his status will be informed that he is an NPP voter.  
11  Attached hereto as Exhibit F is a screenshot of what that NPP voter who has not applied to vote by 
12  mail (i.e., will be voting in person at a polling place) would see.  If the NPP voter has applied to vote

14  presidential primaries, he must request a crossover ballot for one of the three political parties that have 
15  opened their presidential primaries to NPP voters.  Attached hereto as Exhibit G is a screenshot of 
16  what such a voter would see. 
17  11.  Fifth, an NPP voter who signs up on the Department’s website to vote by mail will be 
18  provided with similar information.  The first step in the online application process is to enter the 
19  voter’s house number, zip code, and date of birth.  Attached hereto as Exhibit H is a screenshot of this 
20  initial page.3  From this information, the Department can determine if the person is an NPP voter.  If 
21  so, the voter is informed that he has the option of voting in one of the presidential primaries, and that 
22  to do so, he must fill out an application.  Attached hereto as Exhibit I is a screenshot of this page.  This 
23  page contains a link to that application.  A true and correct copy of that application is attached hereto 
24  as Exhibit J.

1  12.  Sixth, the Department has trained all poll workers to inform NPP voters that they have 
2  the option of voting for one of the three designated parties.  A true and correct copy of the relevant 
3  excerpts of the poll worker training manual is attached hereto as Exhibit K.4  Pages 37-50 discuss the 
4  fact that NPP voters should be offered a presidential primary ballot for the three political parties that

6  Francisco has a sign informing NPP voters that they may vote in one of these primaries.  A true and 
7  correct copy of such a sign is attached hereto as Exhibit L. 
8  13.  Seventh, the VIP, which, as noted above, is provided to every registered San Francisco 
9  voter and is available on the Department’s website, provides answers to questions such as “What does

13  NPP voters may vote in any of the three designated presidential primaries, whereas voters registered 
14  for a political party may only vote in the party’s presidential primary.  See Ex. D at 13.  In addition, a 
15  letter I wrote that appears near the front of the VIP explains that “the party preference that voters 
16  selected when registering to vote determines which candidates will appear on their ballots for these 
17  contests,” but that three parties have allowed NPP voters to vote in their primaries.  See Ex. D at 4.   
18  14.  Eighth, on April 5, 2016, the Department sent a mailer to every household in San 
19  Francisco—over 362,000 in all—reminding them to vote and stating: “To learn what’s on the ballot 
20  and why your political party preference makes a difference in the Presidential Primary, go to 
21  sfelections.org/June2016.”  A true and correct copy of such a mailer is attached hereto as Exhibit M.  
22  The link on the mailer, among other things, informs NPP voters that they can vote in the presidential 
23  primary for any of the three designated parties.  A true and correct copy of the website referenced on 
24  the mailer is attached hereto as Exhibit N.5
